Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stood in the polling station, ballot envelope in hand, my heart thumping. The poll worker pointed out the smudge on my signature and politely asked me to re-sign, explaining it was to ensure my vote would count. I nodded, but my mind raced back to my mother’s words that morning: “Never change your signature once you’ve signed something important. It’s a matter of integrity—our family’s way.” I’d grown up with these traditions, watching my parents treat every signature as a solemn promise, never to be altered or redone. Now, as a voter, I was expected to follow the poll worker’s instructions, to trust the process and do what was necessary for my ballot to be valid. But as a daughter, I felt the weight of my family’s values pressing on me, warning me not to betray what I’d been taught. My hand hovered over the envelope, torn between honoring my family’s tradition and fulfilling my civic duty. The poll worker waited patiently, but inside, I was caught in a storm of loyalty and responsibility, unsure which role I could bear to disappoint.
